dt: {bc}an outrageous, improper, vicious, or immoral act
{bc}the quality or state of being immoderate, monstrous, or outrageous

dt.t: the {wi}enormity{/wi} of the crimes committed during the Third Reich

dt: {bc}the quality or state of being huge {bc}{sx|immensity||}
{bc}a quality of momentous importance or impact

pt: {it}Enormity{/it}, some people insist, is improperly used to denote large size. They insist on {it}enormousness{/it} for this meaning, and would limit {it}enormity{/it} to the meaning "great wickedness." Those who urge such a limitation may not recognize the subtlety with which {it}enormity{/it} is actually used. It regularly denotes a considerable departure from the expected or normal.

pt.t: they awakened; they sat up; and then the {it}enormity{/it} of their situation burst upon them. "How did the fire start?"

pt: When used to denote large size, either literal or figurative, it usually suggests something so large as to seem overwhelming

pt.t: no intermediate zone of study. Either the {it}enormity{/it} of the desert or the sight of a tiny flower
the {it}enormity{/it} of the task of teachers in slum schools

pt: and may even be used to suggest both great size and deviation from morality.

pt.t: the {it}enormity{/it} of existing stockpiles of atomic weapons

pt: It can also emphasize the momentousness of what has happened

pt.t: the sombre {it}enormity{/it} of the Russian Revolution
perceived as no one in the family could the {it}enormity{/it} of the misfortune

shortdef: an outrageous, improper, vicious, or immoral act
the quality or state of being immoderate, monstrous, or outrageous; especially : great wickedness
the quality or state of being huge : immensity
